history.content:
A spanning tree connects all vertices together such that removing an edge leaves the tree disjoint; additionally it of course shares its edges with the edges of the original graph

A minimum spanning tree does all of that, plus the [sum of weights of the] set of edges is of minimum possible weight too.

There may be more than 1 minimum spanning tree; as you rightly say, they would be of equal, minimal, weight

The $$\le$$ condition is often easier to prove / simpler to leverage than strict equality, is the reason you see it bandied around 

HTH

A spanning tree connects all vertices together such that removing an edge leaves the tree disjoint; additionally it of course shares its edges with the edges of the original graph

A minimum spanning tree does all of that, plus the set of edges is of minimum possible weight too.

There may be more than 1 minimum spanning tree; as you rightly say, they would be of equal, minimal, weight

The $$\le$$ condition is often easier to prove / simpler to leverage than strict equality, is the reason you see it bandied around 

HTH

A minimum spanning tree is both 
- minumum: in the sense that the sum of the weight of the edges is the lowest possible sum
and..
- spanning: connects all the vertices in the graph , so that it is a tree.

There could be multiple possible minimum spanning trees that have the equal weight and connecting all the vertices!

children.subject:
"The ≤ condition is often easier to prove / simpler to leverage than strict equality, is the reason you see it bandied around " Thanks Mark, I was actually wondering WHY <= was used instead of just ==, but I guess as you pointed out its just easier to prove (although intuitively I guess we see its =).

Also, +1 for the term 'bandied', it should be used more often!

history.content: Im confused about the definition of a minimum spanning tree. Is it just that it connects all vertices together such that removing any edge leaves the tree disjoint, or does it also mean that this set of edges is of minimum possible weight? a few times it has been discussed that there are multiple possible minimum spanning trees, such as problem 3) of our homework, where there is also another minimum spanning tree of weight <= the weight of the original tree. But if the original tree is a minimum spanning tree, I thought this meant it had to be of minimal weight, so any other minimum spanning tree would have to be of equal weight... where am I miss-understanding?
history.subject: is a minimum spanning tree always minimum weight?
